Given a folder path, check if it exists, and if not, creates it :param dird: path :return:

bel.toolbox.file_ops.keep_essential(res_dir)¶

Deletes everything in a simulation folder except specific files. :param res_dir: Path to the folder containing results :return:

bel.toolbox.file_ops.load_data(res_dir, n=0, check=True, data_flag=False)¶
Parameters

  • check – Whether to check breaktrough curves for unrealistic results or not.

  • res_dir – main directory containing results sub-directories

  • n – if != 0, will randomly select n sub-folders from res_tree

  • data_flag – if True, only loads data and not the target

Returns

tp, sd

bel.toolbox.hausdorff module¶

bel.toolbox.hausdorff.modified_distance(a, b)¶

Compute the modified Hausdorff distance between two N-D arrays. Distances between pairs are calculated using a Euclidean metric.

a(M,N) ndarray

Input array.

b(O,N) ndarray

Input array.

ddouble

The modified Hausdorff distance between arrays a and b.

ValueError

An exception is thrown if a and b do not have the same number of columns.

1

M. P. Dubuisson and A. K. Jain. A Modified Hausdorff distance for object matching. In ICPR94, pages A:566-568, Jerusalem, Israel, 1994. http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpls/abs_all.jsp?arnumber=576361

Another Python implementation. https://github.com/sapphire008/Python/blob/master/generic/HausdorffDistance.py

bel.toolbox.mesh_ops module¶

bel.toolbox.mesh_ops.blocks_from_rc(rows, columns)¶

Returns the blocks forming a 2D grid whose rows and columns widths are defined by the two arrays rows, columns

bel.toolbox.mesh_ops.blocks_from_rc_3d(rows, columns)¶

Returns the blocks forming a 2D grid whose rows and columns widths are defined by the two arrays rows, columns

bel.toolbox.mesh_ops.blockshaped(arr, nrows, ncols)¶

Return an array of shape (n, nrows, ncols) where n * nrows * ncols = arr.size

If arr is a 2D array, the returned array should look like n sub-blocks with each sub-block preserving the “physical” layout of arr.

bel.toolbox.mesh_ops.h_sub(h, un, uc, sc)¶

Process signed distance array. :param h: Signed distance array :param un: # rows :param uc: # columns :param sc: New cell dimension in x and y direction (original is 1)

bel.toolbox.mesh_ops.matrix_paste(c_big, c_small)¶

bel.toolbox.plots module¶

class bel.toolbox.plots.Plot(x_lim=None, y_lim=None, grf=5)¶

Bases: object

contours_vertices(arrays, c=0)¶
curves(tc, n_wel, sdir=None, show=False)¶

Shows every breakthrough curve stacked on a plot. :param tc: Curves with shape (n_sim, n_wells, n_time_steps) :param n_wel: Number of observation points :param sdir: Directory in which to save figure :param show: Whether to show or not

curves_i(tc, n_wel, sdir=None, show=False)¶

Shows every breakthrough individually for each observation point. Will produce n_well figures of n_sim curves each. :param tc: Curves with shape (n_sim, n_wells, n_time_steps) :param n_wel: Number of observation points :param sdir: Directory in which to save figure :param show: Whether to show or not

h_pca_inverse_plot(pca_o, e, vn)¶

Plot used to compare the reproduction of the original physical space after PCA transformation :param e: Sample number on which the test is performed :param pca_o: signed distance PCA operator :param vn: Number of components to inverse-transform. :return:

pca_inverse_compare(pco_d, pco_h, nd, nh)¶

Plots original data and recovered data by PCA inverse transformation given a number of components :param pco_h: PCA object for h :param pco_d: PCA object for d :param nd: number of components in d :param nh: number of components in h :return:

whp(h=None, alpha=0.4, lw=0.5, bkg_field_array=None, vmin=None, vmax=None, x_lim=None, y_lim=None, cmap='coolwarm', colors='white', show_wells=False, fig_file=None, show=False)¶

Produces the WHPA plot, that is the zero-contour of the signed distance array. It assumes that well information can be loaded from pw.npy and iw.npy. I should change this. :param show_wells: whether to plot well coordinates or not :param cmap: colormap for the background array :param vmax: max value to plot for the background array :param vmin: max value to plot for the background array :param bkg_field_array: 2D array whose values will be plotted on the grid :param h: Array containing grids of values whose 0 contour will be computed and plotted :param alpha: opacity of the 0 contour lines :param lw: Line width :param colors: Line color :param fig_file: :param show: :param x_lim: [x_min, x_max] :param y_lim: [y_min, y_max]

whp_prediction(forecasts, h_true, h_pred, fig_file=None, show_wells=False, show=False)¶
bel.toolbox.plots.cca(cca_operator, d, h, d_pc_prediction, h_pc_prediction, sdir=None, show=False)¶

CCA plots. Receives d, h PC components to be predicted, transforms them in CCA space and adds it to the plots. :param cca_operator: CCA operator :param d: d CCA scores :param h: h CCA scores :param d_pc_prediction: d test PC scores :param h_pc_prediction: h test PC scores :param sdir: :param show: :return:

bel.toolbox.plots.d_pca_inverse_plot(v, e, pca_o, vn)¶

Plot used to compare the reproduction of the original physical space after PCA transformation :param v: Original, untransformed data array :param e: Sample number on which the test is performed :param pca_o: data PCA operator :param vn: Number of components to inverse-transform the data :return:

bel.toolbox.plots.explained_variance(pca, n_comp=0, xfs=2, fig_file=None, show=False)¶

PCA explained variance plot :param pca: PCA operator :param n_comp: Number of components to display :param xfs: X-axis fontsize :param fig_file: :param show: :return:

bel.toolbox.plots.pca_scores(training, prediction, n_comp, fig_file=None, show=False)¶

PCA scores plot, displays scores of observations above those of training. :param training: Training scores :param prediction: Test scores :param n_comp: How many components to show :param fig_file: :param show: :return:

bel.toolbox.posterior_ops module¶

class bel.toolbox.posterior_ops.PosteriorOps¶

Bases: object

posterior(h_cca_training_gaussian, d_cca_training, d_pc_training, d_rotations, d_cca_prediction)¶

Estimating posterior uncertainties.

Parameters

  • h_cca_training_gaussian – Canonical Variate of the training target, Gaussian-distributed

  • d_cca_training – Canonical Variate of the training data

  • d_pc_training – Principal Components of the training data

  • d_rotations – CCA rotations of the training data

  • d_cca_prediction – Canonical Variate of the observation

Returns

h_mean_posterior, h_posterior_covariance

ValueError

An exception is thrown if the shape of input arrays are not consistent.

1

A. Tarantola. Inverse Problem Theory and Methods for Model Parameter Estimation. SIAM, 2005. Pages: 70-71

random_sample(sample_n, pca_d, pca_h, cca_obj, n_posts=1, add_comp=0)¶
